Award.AwardTitle: Complex Effects of Climate Change on Nature Reserve Networks at Macroscales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Protected areas such as nature reserves have been a major cornerstone of biodiversity conservation. However, human activities have compromised conservation goals in many nature reserves, and climate change poses additional threats to their long-term viability and success. Although some studies have analyzed climate change impacts on the conservation effectiveness of nature reserves, most have focused on individual nature reserves in localized regions. Funding is provided to assess the changes in species distribution within and across networks of nature reserves in broad geographic regions, and to analyze the effects of climate change on the long-term survival of plant and animal species. An exceptional setting for achieving the objectives is the globally important forested macrosystem that is the historical geographic range of the world-famous endangered giant panda (2.2 million km2 across 19 provinces of China). Across this vast macrosystem there are currently 63 panda reserves and over 1,000 reserves for other purposes, which together constitute a reserve meta-network (network of networks). Using state-of-the-art climate change projections, remote sensing techniques, meta-uncertainty analyses, and species distribution models, a multi-disciplinary and international team of researchers will analyze climate change impacts on conservation effectiveness of this meta-network of reserves as well as current and future geographic distribution of the panda and around 30 bamboo species that comprise 99% of its diet.

This project will lead to transformative and significant outcomes, such as testing and extending two fundamental theories (niche theory and connectivity theory) at macroscales. It will also generate powerful and lasting broader impacts. Through active engagement with stakeholders, the research team will use project results to develop and evaluate effective and efficient conservation strategies of global importance in the context of climate change. Improving conservation strategies for a well-known charismatic endangered species will help to increase the public awareness of the potential climate change impacts on biodiversity, and encourage public engagement on climate change mitigation and adaptation. Through strategic communication and hands-on workshops, the results and methods will be widely disseminated to inspire others to analyze the impacts of climate change on other species and other nature reserve networks around the world. Furthermore, the project will train undergraduate and graduate students as well as post-doctoral scholars, who will gain broad and deep knowledge and learn important skills to become future visionary leaders and globally-engaged researchers who can creatively address future challenges to biodiversity research and conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nature reserves are a major cornerstone of biodiversity conservation. However, human activities compromise the conservation goals of many nature reserves, and climate change poses additional threats to their long-term viability and effectiveness. To enhance the success of biodiversity conservation over the long run it is crucial to develop new strategies and advance theories to evaluate their long-term effectiveness, particularly under the context of climate change. This project advanced important theories (e.g., niche, connectivity) and evaluated the impacts of climate change on species distribution within and across a nature reserve meta-network (a network of reserve networks) covering a broad geographic region comprising the current and historical geographic range of the giant panda (2.2 million km^2 across 19 provinces of China), an icon of biodiversity conservation. Across this vast macrosystem there are currently 67 nature reserves established specifically for the conservation of the giant panda and more than 1,000 reserves established for other purposes.

The project resulted in numerous peer-reviewed publications that contributed to the advancement of multiple disciplines, including macrosystems biology, climate science, ecology, land change science, coupled human and natural systems research, conservation biology, and sustainability science. For instance, the project found that the establishment of nature reserves, together with forest conservation programs extending beyond their boundaries, were instrumental in the significant increase in forest cover and giant panda habitat observed over the last couple of decades. This contributed to the downlisting of the giant panda from endangered to vulnerable by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. In addition, it was found that the use of charismatic umbrella species, such as the giant panda, as surrogates for the conservation of entire biodiversity pools was effective, although with important limitations as not all species were benefitted. Since climate change may negatively impact these conservation successes, the project also advanced our understanding of the impacts of climate change on conservation. By focusing on the quantification of model uncertainty, the project made significant advances in species distribution modeling, a crucial component of conservation planning under current and projected future climate conditions. Several sources of uncertainty, and their interactions, were evaluated, including the effects of geographic extent, grain size and niche breadth to conclude that species occurrence predictions can be substantially improved by evaluating models at multiple grain sizes and extents. The choice of baseline climate information and the limitations of species occurrence data (e.g., location error, sampling bias, species misidentification) used in model calibration were also assessed. These sources of uncertainty can be as large or even larger than routinely-considered sources of uncertainty, such as the choice of future climate projection, yet they have been largely neglected. Ignoring these sources of uncertainty may compromise the proper interpretation of species distribution modeling outputs and reduce their usefulness for conservation planning. After accounting for these different sources of uncertainty, the project advanced the concept of climate change refugia. These constitute suitable areas for the long-term protection of species from the negative effects of anthropogenic climate change. In spite of their significance, climate change refugia have rarely been considered in conservation planning. Using this perspective, the project successfully evaluated the long-term effectiveness of different conservation strategies, including the establishment of interconnected nature reserves and species reintroductions. Such evaluation contributed to the prioritization of available resources and identification of strategic modifications to conservation management oriented to increase its adaptive capacity while avoiding maladaptation to climate change.

The project also made substantial contributions in several other disciplines and global efforts for conservation and sustainability, including an evaluation of the synergies and tradeoffs among the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) within and across nature reserve boundaries. Such evaluation proved to be beneficial for global sustainability. In addition, the project explored the inclusion of the metacoupling framework (which incorporates the study of ecological and socioeconomic dimensions and their interactions within, between, and among adjacent and distant places) into macrosystems biology. These and many other contributions of the project advanced not only different research frontiers but also generated novel methodological and analytical approaches that will stimulate innovative scientific discoveries and help address current global challenges.

The junior scholars (post-docs, graduate students) that worked in the project benefitted widely through the project's international and multi-disciplinary research collaborations, while also obtaining hands-on experience on data collection, management and analysis. These scholars were also trained on how to communicate research results in professional meetings, peer-reviewed journals and to the general public through social media and global news media. The project personnel also interacted with multiple stakeholders, particularly those involved in biodiversity conservation. These interactions not only resulted in the co-production and publication of research results in academic journals and an edited book, but also provided useful information to enthuse the incorporation of research results into education of the general public, as well as into decision making processes in conservation management.
